headline: The Source with Kaitlan Collins
subHeadline: Closing Arguments Over In Trump Trial; Transcript Released Of Closing Arguments In Trump Trial; 12 Georgia Voters Weigh In On Trump Hush Money Case. Aired 9-10p ET

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: It is just before 9 PM, here in New York.The end of a nearly 12-hour day, for jurors, in the first of the former President's four criminal trials. They'll get the case, tomorrow. And with it, a job that no juries ever had before, deciding whether or not to convict a former President of the United States, and current candidate for the Office again, of as many as 34 felonies. Today, it was the final chance, for both sides, to persuade them. We're talking about it tonight. Joining the panel, retired New York City criminal judge, George Grasso; and jury consultant, Alan Tuerkheimer. Judge Grasso, it is great to have you with all your experience here. What do you make of closing arguments, tonight? I mean, five hours, two and a half, three hours, is that?

utterances.speaker: GEORGE GRASSO, RETIRED NYC CRIMINAL COURT JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Well, it was a -- it was a long day. For the most part, I found it, I was totally zoned in. That went pretty -- went pretty quick. I felt, towards the last hour or so that Mr. Steinglass could have moved it along. And I didn't know if we needed like six book excerpts.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: NORMAN EISEN, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: They were a choice, George.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Choice excerpt. I think less would have been a little more with some of that.But I think -- I think, look, on the defense end to -- I think Todd Blanche was, I heard the word, meandering.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: I certainly subscribe to that.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. GRASSO

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Do you think he should not have even brought those up?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: If anything, I wouldn't -- he like lead with it.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: That's not him -- those documents are not his strong suit.And I anticipated. And then I saw Steinglass just went to town. He really, he got an A-plus on that. He had both documents up. You've got Weisselberg's handwriting on the documents, laying out the scheme, the $420,000. You got McConney on a separate document number 36 with his handwriting, parroting the same scheme. And just so we have a trifecta, on 35, you got Cohen's handwriting too.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Well and one thing that Steinglass seemed to drill in on was he was seen to be making fun of Todd Blanche. That was kind of the tone that he tried to adopt the whole time.But he was saying, this idea that Todd Blanche is arguing that because these documents exist show that no crime was committed here, that no documents were falsified, because you can see them. He was saying, there never would be a business falsification case ever--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: --because they would just destroy them. And if they existed, they would say, well, it's not a crime.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And that was something he kind of, he looked to the committee and said, you almost have to -- to the jury and said, you almost have to laugh at the way Mr. Blanche explained it to you.You've been in there every single day. You sit in the same seat, for people who don't know.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Everyone else has to fight for a seat. He has his own same seat, which I'm obsessed with.But I'm wondering what you make of how that sat with the jury as they're watching this.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: You mean what Blanche did with the--

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: On how Steinglass kind of turned it around?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Oh, I think -- I think putting it all together, I think if it's a tennis match, I mean, Steinglass just nailed them. He put it over the net and killed it.And I think the jury -- this is a smart jury. I mean, we all look at the same jury. We see the same jury. We were there for the -- Norman and I were there for the questioning of the jurors. These are people, who want to be there. They could have just raised their hand, if they didn't want to be there. They would have -- they would have left. They've been through the whole process. Today was day 21. They're clearly paying attention. This was not over their head.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Alan?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: They got this.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Alan, you're a jury consultant. There's a lot of talk about the length of the closing arguments. Had you ever come across jurors, who were so annoyed about the duration that it actually impacted their votes?

utterances.speaker: ALAN TUERKHEIMER, JURY CONSULTANT
utterances.sentences: I don't think it impacted their votes.And I think since both sides went excessively long, with their closings, I think it's probably a draw, in terms of which side seemed to be a little more tedious, a little more in the weeds, a little more on extraneous information that they didn't need. So, I think each side, they did OK, they did a good job. But they missed delivering stellar closings. Now, the defense, I think, did what it had to. It raised some questions about fraudulent intent, on the part of Trump, regarding the invoices, surrounding the payments. But they were a little gratuitous with some cheap shots, at Michael Cohen and a little gimmicky. Prosecution, I think, was a little more streamlined. They give a timeline, laid out the elements, and the actual verdict questions jurors are going to have. But the State also took a long time. So, at this point, it's about deliberation advocacy. And I would guess that of the 12 jurors, maybe four of them are pretty firmly convinced of guilt or innocence, and then another four are leaning in one direction or the other. And then, four are waiting for deliberations to make a decision.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: And Judge, if a jury can't reach a decision, if they're deadlocked, there's something called an Allen charge.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: That the judge can give to them.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: What is that?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: It's basically, it's kind of like looking at them. You took an oath. I believe in you. You believe in me.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, but --

utterances.speaker: ELIE HONIG, CNN SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: That's the nice--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: We can do this.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: --this is the nice way it's done. There's a mean way it's done.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Is this -- is this like putting the thumbscrews?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well, well, well, no, Merchan is going to do it nicely. You know, he's.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: But that -- but that's where--

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: So, wait, you can do the Allen charge nice, or you can do it rough. Is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think what may very well get us to the verdict here is I think Merchan has a ton of goodwill with this jury, a ton of goodwill with this jury. I think if -- for no other reason, they're not going to want to disappoint him.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: He's been protecting the jury, in the sense of like, kind to them. We'd like to go along. But if any one of you has any issue, we won't do it. And they didn't go along one day, because--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: 100 percent.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: --some juror couldn't do it.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: 100 percent. So, he's got a lot of goodwill in the bank there.

utterances.speaker: ARTHUR AIDALA, CRIMINAL DEFENSE ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Judge Grasso, can I -- and since you have the experience here, could you tell us what a missing witness charge is? Because that is in the realm of possibilities. I don't think Judge Merchan has ruled publicly--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --whether he's going to give a missing witness charge. But regarding Weisselberg?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Just tell them what that means.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Because that's a huge win for the defense--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --if he gives a missing witness charge.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Here's why I don't think they're going to give it. Because Arthur, let me tell you--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Yes, could you just tell us about this first?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's got to be a witness that's peculiarly -- peculiarly under the control of the People. So, what that would typically mean, someone's locked up. You're the defense attorney. You can't--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Well he's locked up.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes. But they could get them. Merchan called that bluff.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: But he's going to -- but no but he's -- the defense said we're going to--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --he would take the Fifth, if we call him.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: But the prosecutor could give him immunity.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well let me answer the question. I was in the courtroom, Norman was in the courtroom, when that issue came up. And Merchan said -- because it came up, because I actually thought that the D.A. was playing a little bit of a game with the exit agreement with the $2 million that they wanted to be able to get that in evidence.And then, Merchan said, well, did you try and get him yet? He asked him that question. And then Steinglass was kind of hemming and hawing with that a little bit. So, Merchan says, OK, what about we bring him in, we bring Weisselberg in, outside the presence of the jury, and we question him? Blanche, without -- in a heartbeat, jumped up, he's not on the witnesses list, Judge, we're not ready for him. We don't. And it was so obvious he was -- he was objecting. And then Merchan, and the way Merchan does it, he looked at him, and he said, oh, so this is the first time you're considering that Allen Weisselberg might be a witness in this case? After Merchan did that, and it was obvious he could have brought him in if he wanted. He's not interested in bringing him in, to try and say this is peculiarly under the control of the government. So you get that charge, Arthur. That's why I don't see it.

utterances.speaker: ABBY PHILLIP, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes, neither. I mean, it's -- in that instance, neither side wanted Weisselberg to come in. Not to mention the fact that even if Weisselberg were to testify, it's not clear that he would be a witness for the prosecution. That is not clear at all.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He definitely wouldn't.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Did the defense harp on it in summation?

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Did the defense harp on it?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: No. Because they don't want--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: It was very interesting.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: They don't want him to come in either.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: Judge--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: No, but in summation, it's too late. I'd say like, where's Weisselberg? This is his writing. Here is Exhibit 35. Judge Grasso is really upset about this. It's all his handwriting.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You know what?(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Where is he, folks?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Arthur?

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: They have the burden.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: They did that with some other witnesses. They made that point, right?Blanche basically made that point, on a number of occasions, saying, you know, the prosecution, they didn't bring in any lawmakers, to talk about the impact of the Access Hollywood tape. They didn't bring in that person. They didn't bring in this person. They did it kind of obliquely, but they did not do it for Weisselberg. And I thought that was extremely notable.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: The most ridiculous example of this was when the defense tasked the prosecution with not bringing in Don Jr. and Eric.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Right. Right. Yes.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: It was another one of those--

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Because they were also people, who signed the checks.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: --that misfired.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: And Arthur, I can tell you, we're not getting a missing witness instruction. Because we sat through at lengthy charging conference, it was not discussed. It's not in any of the submissions. Not happening.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: So maybe in the -- so like OK, I got you.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: Maybe they didn't request it--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: We have like the ultimate two trial groupies, right here, with you. We love that.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: You've been to like every motion.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: It would be a lot. And that's--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: It's even worse. Afterwards--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: --we stand in the hallway--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: I think we're--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: --arguing about it, like it's Shakespeare.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes, we'll do it again on Sunday.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: For hours.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's such a bogus issue. Because Pecker is already -- David Pecker has already testified that he didn't provide the counsel with pertinent information. He just, here, take a look at this.None of the background information, none of the -- none of the things going on behind-the-scenes with campaign and money, they're not being reported. It's just like here, Counsel, look at in half hour. Yes, this is good. Trump knows that. Trump's lawyers know that. And, they just want to try and muddy the waters with it. But it wasn't like they got it a legitimate opinion from their General Counsel.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: I was general counsel for the police department for five years. You're going to ask me for an opinion? Submit all the relevant, pertinent information. Don't hold back information, and then take my -- Deputy Commissioner Grasso's opinion, and then hold that up as a legal opinion, because it's not. And that's exactly the game they're trying to pull here.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Judge, if I can -- if I can ask you. Do you see any potential appellate issue with the way the D.A. has charged this case? For the first time in New York history, they've essentially--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: --imported a federal campaign finance violation into a state charge.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Norman and I have been talking about this ad nauseam.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I figured.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Seems like you guys are talking about everything.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Shockingly.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Even on Sunday.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Well I want to hear where the Judge comes out. I know where Norm comes out. I want to hear where you come out.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, it still is, I give the -- overall, I give the D.A. very high marks, absent six book excerpts, on this summation. But it's still a little tricky to figure out how the -- I think as far as the falsified business records?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: I think it's almost slam-dunk right now that they've got Trump pretty solid. I think that this summation for the D.A. buttoned up a lot of that.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes. GRASSO

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: And what is the actual? I still have not seen the final charges to the jury. I'm going to be, as a real nerd on this, I'm going to be like zoning right in. I want to see where they're using willful, what they're going to be using for state of mind. And whatever they use, I think that this is definitely a potential appellate issue.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: But Judge, to Elie's point?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: A lot of appellate issues, a lot of cases that are overturned are overturned on the judge's charge to the jury.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Basically, you gave the rules of the game, to the people deciding the game inaccurately.And you've been there every day.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: For you to say, after summations, prosecutors have done a great job, but it's a little willy-nilly--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --on how they're going to get there--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: --I'm saying that because--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --gives me pause about whether this case should have been brought at all.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well, I -- you know what? I think it's -- I disagree with you on that. And we've had this conversation on your radio show.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Every day.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Every day. Every day.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: I think it was -- there was something rotten in Denmark there. And I think there's a mountain of evidence that -- and I think that that -- the Trump Tower conspiracy meeting, August of 2015, I think the defense summation fell really flat, when they tried to say that like David Pecker had no knowledge of what catch-and-kill, because he didn't use the word. There's a 130,000, 150,000, 30,000 that--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: I know, Judge. But--

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: No, let me finish. That was clearly -- that was clearly--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Sure, judge.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: --that was clearly directed towards the campaign. At least, to me, going there every day, you'd have to be kind of deaf, dumb and blind, not to see that.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: But a minute ago, you said it's willy-nilly.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Will that be -- will--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: A minute ago.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well -- well -- well I'm talking about it.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: You do like this, like you're riding a bike.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: No. No. I'm talking--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: You're like it's a little willy-nilly.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: No. I'm talking about it in the context of what is the charge going to look like? How is the jury going to process it? And what is it going to look like on appeal? Because there is some new ground being made here, so.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Last question. In all your years on the bench, over a decade, did you ever have a charge that it was the first time ever you created the charge? It didn't exist anywhere else? I could give you the answer. The answer is no.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Well, I never had a guy, who ran for president, who thought it was a good idea to get some friends together.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Well there we go.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: And got a lot of money together. We had -- we had--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: And now we have what's called selective prosecution.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: --we had -- no, we have -- we have something here that never happened before. These laws were never used the way they were used before, because they were never, at least from what I've seen, abused the way they were abused by this particular defendant.Now, does that ultimately lead to a bulletproof -- a bulletproof verdict, if they do choose to find him guilty? We'll have to see. But I think the evidence was there to bring the case. I think the evidence is there to convict. But we'll have to ultimately see if he's convicted what the appellate division does.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: There you go, with Judge Grasso.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: They're paying attention.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: I'm taking notes vigorously. And so, I'm always into the notes. But then I just like randomly look up, and scan. And these people are paying attention. They're serious.What do you think, Norman?

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: As smart and dedicated and focused a jury, as I've ever seen, in over 30 years. But never sitting above the courtroom, wearing the robe.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Judge Grasso. Wow. So great to have you. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Pleasure is mine. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Alan Tuerkheimer, as well. Thank you so much. Appreciate it.Coming up next. John Berman's back with more details from the trial transcript. Later, how today's closing arguments landed with voters, specifically in Georgia, people from both sides of the political spectrum. They'll be talking to our Gary Tuchman, live, as our special primetime coverage continues. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: So, Danya Perry, who represented Michael Cohen, was on, a few minutes ago. And she was saying that Michael Cohen actually counted the number of times that Todd Blanche, the defense attorney, called him a liar. So did we. The number we came up with, Anna Glickman, my producer,between calling Michael Cohen a liar, that he was lying, he lied, or just lie, or perjury, 78 times. 78 times, Todd Blanche said it.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Too close.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Close.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: and this is what one of the things that Blanche said, directly about Michael Cohen. He's literally like an MVP of liars. He lies constantly. He's lied to Congress. He lied to prosecutors. He lied to his family, his business associates. He lied to his bosses. He lies to reporters. He lies to Federal Judges.A little bit later, he said, it's like what people, when they talk about with athletes like Michael Jordan as the GOAT; Tiger Woods as the GOAT; Tom Brady as the GOAT, these athletes are the "Greatest of All Time," the best among their peers. Michael Cohen is the GLOAT. He's literally the Greatest Liar of All Time. And then, the prosecutor, Josh Steinglass, later said, we didn't choose Michael Cohen to be our witness. We didn't pick him up at the witness store. The Defendant chose Michael Cohen to be his fixer, because he was willing to lie and cheat on Mr. Trump's behalf. In this case, there is, literally, a mountain of evidence of corroborating testimony that tends to connect the Defendant to this crime; from Pecker, to Hicks, to the Defendant's own employees, to the documents, to the Defendant's own Tweets and rallies, and his own words on that recorded conversation. The list goes on and on. It's difficult to conceive of a case with more corroboration than this one.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: I just want to point out both attorneys misused the word, literally.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: It's just -- it's just a dramatical--

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: We were talking beforehand if I should break that up.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: --make sure, yes.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: We opted not to.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: It's just a little pet peeve of mine.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Another interesting thing is Todd Blanche used the word, Michael Cohen, 251 times. So, he mentioned Michael Cohen 251 times in his closings. He said President Trump or Defendant, 235 times. So more Cohen and Trump. If you want to know what Todd Blanche, who he wants this case to be about, it's right there.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: You should never say the word, defendant. When you're a defense attorney, you never refer to your client as the defendant. He's always Mr. So-and-so, and you put your hand on their shoulder, you know.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: I know. He's never -- to Todd Blanche, he's never Mr. So-and- so.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Well the President.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: He's President Trump.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Well, but apparently, you referred to him as--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: President.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --as the defendant.I mean, look, he has to go after Cohen. And again, I would have just highlighted and -- he lied to all those people, the list you just gave us, Berman. But -- and then I would say and he lied to you folks.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: He did do that.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Do you really think--

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: He did--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --he doesn't want Trump to get acquitted?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And he--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: You really think that's not in his best interest, for President Trump to get -- I'm sorry, do you really think he wants to get him acquitted, not convicted? He's selling shirts of the guy behind bars.Have you -- and using your commonsense, ladies and gentlemen, have you ever heard a case? Think of Law & Order. Think of every movie you've watched. Have you ever seen the main witness is selling T-shirts of the defendant who he is testifying against, wearing a -- in a T-shirt with the guy behind bars? If that doesn't tell you he's lying to you, right here, in this trial, I don't know what is.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, and Steinglass sought to really go -- he spent, it seemed like the first half hour that he was up there, talking about all the times that Todd Blanche called Michael Cohen a liar, and was saying we're not asking you to love Michael Cohen.He was saying Michael Cohen made his bed. But he was saying also one, on Michael Cohen making money, said you can't judge him for making money, off the people that he surrounded himself with, drawing it all back to saying, Donald Trump was the person who put Michael Cohen in this position, and hired him for all these years. And another interesting point, and on the Trump going to jail, he said, quote, anyone in Cohen's shoes would want the defendant to be held accountable. That's how they addressed that. But he also made an interesting point. He said that the defense was trying to have it both ways, with Michael Cohen, which is to say he's a liar, and he's a thief. But also, this idea that he was not -- he was not being reimbursed, that he was being paid these legal fees that are totally aboveboard, but also he got $60,000 that were grossed up for taxes, which is not as you well know, how legal fees work. They were arguing the defense was making two different arguments about Michael Cohen that conflicted with one another.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: They were also pointing out that Michael Cohen wants credit for things, and certainly wants attention for the things he has done. So, the idea that he would have done this without Donald Trump's knowledge, just is not -- that he's going to want the -- to get the credit from Donald Trump, for having done this.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: I thought it was interesting, how Josh Steinglass, the prosecutor, dealt with the Michael Cohen issue, because he took the most damaging testimony, upfront.He stepped -- before he did his long chronological summary, he took that moment. You and I were sitting very near each other, for that moment, Anderson, when he confronted Michael Cohen with that October 24th phone call, and said you didn't mention that it was about this 14-year-old prank caller. And Cohen, we heard it from his lawyer on the prior hour that Danya Perry said well, my recollection was refreshed, there's plenty of time to do it. Steinglass took the bull by the horns on that, with his wonderful little bit of theater, of doing that phone call, and playing out how there was enough time. He fronted it. And then, the -- it was a one- two punch to defend Michael Cohen. Then he spent another close to four hours on the corroboration of Michael Cohen. That's why we were all kept there so long.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: I had to sprint. I don't know how Kaitlan got here before me, because she was still in court, when I ran out.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Fast.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: She's got that anchor magic.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: But Elie, did you--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: I had to sprint. And he did it -- hold on, Arthur.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: He did it for--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: I'm not going anywhere.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: And I'm going to do it for four hours.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: All right. OK, all right.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: You did the cross-examination you wanted to do.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: I want to ask my man, Elie, a question.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to do my prosecution closing.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: That's all.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: He, for four hours, he corroborated Cohen. And he wanted to make a point, you can believe him, but also there is a mountain. And he made the jury suffer a little bit through that mountain. But the suffering was the point.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Speaking of suffering, might I be heard?Elie, when--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: Your motion is granted.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Thank you.When you were a prosecutor, and you were building up your case, did you do it in a -- in a way, like a timestamp way? Or did you do it issue by issue? Did you do it chronologically, or issue by issue?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I would try to take it chronologically, right? You start thematic, you end thematic. But you want the jury to be able to follow it. This is a hard story to follow. A lot of it happened a long time ago. There's meetings. There's calls. So, I would take it linear. I would never go four hours.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: But I want to say this also. We prosecutors are so spoiled. We have every advantage. I can recognize that now. I did it for 14 years.But take for example, the point that Steinglass made. A very effective rhetorical argument, about we didn't choose him as our witness, the defendant chose him. That's bull. The prosecution chose him, when they chose to charge this case. They own him. They're the ones putting them in front of the jury, saying believe him beyond a reasonable doubt. But Steinglass, and me and my old days, knows that you're getting -- we get the last word, and they're not going to be able to make that rebuttal.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: And they're the ones, who decided not to charge him for stealing $30,000 from this exact transaction.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: But, I mean, Donald Trump is the one, who chose to surround himself with--

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: For sure.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And--

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: --a certain type of people. And Michael Cohen was one of them. And he -- Michael Cohen seemed to flourish under the system, and the cast of characters that Donald Trump wanted to surround him with.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And assigned him to one of the most sensitive undertakings that happened, in the 2016 campaign--

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Right, yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: --which is much as the defense tried to downplay the 2016 Access Hollywood tape. We were all there. We all witnessed it. Michael Cohen was in charge of dealing with that.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: The defense has said the former President did not have a sexual encounter with Stormy Daniels. Today, they also argued that this case is about the documents, not about her.Prosecutors, however, said that, believing her testimony only reinforces why the former President would want to buy her silence. Why else, they asked, did they work so hard to try to discredit her? According the prosecution, in the simplest terms, Stormy Daniels is the motive. This is how she described that alleged 2006 sexual encounter, when I talked to her, in 2018, for "60 Minutes." (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: STORMY DANIELS, ALLEGES AFFAIR WITH DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I went to the restroom. You know, I was in there for a little bit and came out and he was sitting, you know, on the edge of the bed, when I walked out, perched.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: And when you saw that, what went through your mind?

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: I realized exactly what I'd gotten myself into. And I was like, ughh, here we go. And I just felt like maybe it was sort of, I had it coming for making a bad decision, for going to someone's room alone, and I just heard the voice in my head, well, you put yourself in a bad situation and bad things happen, so you deserve this.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: And you had sex with him?

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: You were 27, he was 60. Were you physically attracted to him?

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Not at all?

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Did you want to have sex with him?

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: No. But I didn't -- I didn't say no. I'm not a victim, I'm not--

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: It was entirely consensual.

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: You work in an industry where condom use is -- is an issue. Did the -- did he use a condom?

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Did you ask him to?

utterances.speaker: DANIELS
utterances.sentences: No. I honestly didn't say anything.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: The defense reiterated, today that the former President denies the encounter.Joining us is Stormy Daniels' attorney, Clark Brewster. You think this is going to end quickly? You think a jury could come back quickly with a verdict? CLARK BREWSTER, STORMY DANIELS' ATTORNEY: Yes, I think so. I think the issues are pretty defined. Even though there's 34 counts, I really the -- the facts to the -- to the law, in this case, will be easily applied, in my view, notwithstanding the long closing arguments today. And I predict they'll come back pretty quickly, if not tomorrow, then Thursday.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think his statement was like met at one time, on a golf course, for a picture. But that left out the story about the number of times he called her, that people were witness to, that she'd gone to Trump Tower, and they had pictures up there, that she'd gone to his bungalow in Hollywood. So, I mean, there's a lot of things that he said that weren't true.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, and she testified that it did happen.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump obviously did not testify to whether or not it happened. Do you -- I mean, do you think he should have, if he wants to continue denying it?

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Well, he has an absolute right not to testify, in a court of law, when he's charged, criminally. And so, we respect that.But he said so many things about it outside the courtroom, that you would have thought that he would want to wear that on his sleeve in the courtroom. But he didn't.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Clark, do you think that the prosecution needed to call Stormy Daniels, legally, or narratively?

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Originally, when I first met with the prosecution, it was my position, why do you need to call her?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: I've read the indictment. I didn't think they needed to call her.But I think they really wanted to lay the context for why Trump would have felt, this was a very important thing to keep on to the public view, and that it was something that she was credible. She had a persona in the public. And so, I think it was important, probably, for the jury to see her and understand.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well they described her--

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: When the defense--

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Sorry.When the defense said that the allegations were already out there, they basically said that the idea that suddenly Stormy Daniels' story coming out, in 2016, would not have been that big of a deal, because they were essentially already in the public domain. Do you think there's any truth to that?

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Well, I think there might be some truth to the fact that she'd made a statement, I think, back in 2011, but really hadn't caught traction until the Access Hollywood tape.The Access Hollywood tape put it into a just a, you know, four-corner defense for them. They had to do something, in my view, because she would have been a spokesperson that really would have lent credibility to the story, and would have told the truth, so.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: Some--

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Last time you were here, you told us that Stormy Daniels was so nervous, going to testify, that she actually wore a bulletproof vest--

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: --on her way, inside court. I mean, obviously, she has security, and she was with them. What -- how is she spending these few days, as now the jury is about to get the case, in just a matter of hours?

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I wouldn't say nervous. She wasn't nervous. She was fearful. And she was fearful about what couldn't be predicted that somebody might do something rash, or somebody might try to harm her or her family. And she really got gripped with fear.But when it came to getting on the stand, she was, I thought, she really showed transparency, and forthcoming, and met with cross- examination, and dealt well with it.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But how is she feeling about this moment now, now that the jury is about to get the case, and as she's waiting to see what this verdict is going to be?

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Well, she's been texting me, right up to this moment. So, she's decided not to do any interviews. She wants to stay out of the limelight. She doesn't want to have any bearing whatsoever on whatever the jurors may think. She wants her testimony to be what they've heard and make decisions about. And so, she's just chosen to not do any interviews.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Does she--

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Which I got to say, speaks very well to, to her that she doesn't want to influence this process until the jury renders a verdict.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. The prosecutor shouldn't (ph) ask her not to make any statements, as the trial was getting closer. And she didn't. And she stayed out. She, I think, she responded a little bit in the Twitter- field. But for the most part, no interviews and stayed out.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You want--

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You answered Elie's question, about whether or not you thought she should testify. Does she still think that it was the right thing, for her to actually take the witness stand?

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: I think so. We have a really good relationship. And I share with her what I think she should do. And then, she really has a voice in that and chooses her own course.But I think in the long run, if she were here, she would say she's glad that she showed up, and subjected herself to cross-examination, so that people could see, whether she was telling the truth. And I think they could see that.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: On the topic of the cross-examination. Some of us, myself included, felt that she was actually stronger on cross. Would it have been wiser? One of the themes, as we've talked about today is less is sometimes more, Clark. Would it have been wiser for the defense simply not to cross-examine her? There were some tough moments on the direct.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: My son was with me. And he's a trial lawyer. And we talked about how we might have cross-examined her.And the one thing is there's probably 30 questions that the defense lawyer could ask, that she would have agreed with him on. And they could have gotten to consensus on a lot of detail. But they went in, and challenged her early, and tried to really impugn her integrity, and just didn't go well for them. I think there could have been a real nice pathway, of leading questions, and getting consensus on facts.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Well, there's some -- we could talk about it. But there's many. I mean, she wouldn't have resisted a lot of facts that would have been consistent with Trump's story, and the truth, truly.And the real issue is whether sex occurred, and how it unfolded. And that's where they parted with regard to the story. But there's a lot of consensus they could have reached, in a good examination. It wasn't done.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: I would have just done all the questions on that she did not talk to Trump about the issues in this case, the 34 allegedly false records Trump -- in Trump's intent or not, in creating those records. She never had a conversation with him about the underlying alleged 2016 election conspiracy. So, she really doesn't have any information--

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But they--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: --to advance the case. And she illustrates the distance that the prosecution has to travel for the actual issues in the case.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Yes. There's a lot of ways you could have approached it. But I think going for the issues that they could have agreed upon, would have been a good cross-examination for her.She really prides herself on being truthful and consistent. And I think they could have gotten a long way with that. Ultimately, though, the story would have come out, what happened. And ultimately what drove Trump to act in 2016--

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I mean--

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: --I think that's the case.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: --the prosecution ended today with one of their lines saying that Stormy Daniels was the motive here, that that's the simplest way to put it.The defense was arguing that she was extorting Trump. Because the prosecution was saying, well, this was out there, and he never chose to pay it until close to the election. Todd Blanche was arguing that this was extortion of a presidential candidate. What does she make of, of something like that?

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Well, did Karen McDougal do it as well? I mean -- I mean, aren't they both as similar-situated, although the scheme and trying to silence them was slightly different?Stormy really had little to say. It was Keith Davidson, her lawyer, and they approached him, and he reported to her. It's far from extortion. And trying to make that argument, I think, the jury would see, as not very valid.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Clark Brewster, it's great to have you on again. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: BREWSTER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: This case will soon be in the hands of the 12 jurors. And after that, voters in the November presidential elections, which is only a little more than five months away.Our Gary Tuchman is in Georgia, a key battleground state, with 12 voters, representing a range of opinions, about the former President and the case. Gary, what are you hearing?

utterances.speaker: GARY TUCHMAN, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Anderson, we are here, in Atlanta, with 12 voters, who've done their best, to pay attention to the coverage of this trial. And we've watched the coverage of the closing arguments, tonight.Unlike the jury, in New York City, I've grilled these people, about their politics. I've asked them who they're going to vote for in November, because we want political diversity in this group. I feel we succeeded, because five of you say you're going to vote for Joe Biden, five of you say you're going to vote for Donald Trump. And two of you are undecided. The first thing I want to ask you, though, show of hands, who feels, think like a juror now, who feels that Donald Trump has been proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt? Raise your hand. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven. Who thinks that Donald Trump is not guilty? Raise your hand high. One, two, three, four. We have one undecided person then. Who's undecided? You're undecided. OK. I want to start with you, Ross (ph). You said you're going to vote for Donald Trump. But you think he's guilty. Why? ROSS (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Yes, sir. I think he's guilty, because I don't think in his business dealings that he would not know what was going on with the hush money payments.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.Deanna (ph), you said you're going to vote for Joe Biden. You feel Trump is guilty. Why? DEANNA (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Correct. Yes, I believe that the evidence that was presented was pretty substantial, including the bank account statements, from Michael Cohen, and the series of checks that were signed off by Trump.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Joe (ph), you say you're undecided about who you going to vote for in November. But you feel that Donald Trump is guilty. Why?JOE (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: I do, yes. I've -- same reason, I believe that the -- they proved the money trail, and they hid that for nefarious reasons.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.Joe (ph) and Sandy (ph) are a couple. Sandy (ph) feels differently. She's ready to vote for Donald Trump. SANDY (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And feels he's not guilty.Why do you feel that way? SANDY (ph): I think Michael Cohen is lack of -- a total lack of credibility as a star witness. He's proven to be dishonest, and admitted it as well. And now, we're supposed to believe him, so.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.Robert (ph), you said you're ready to vote for Donald Trump and you feel he's not guilty. Tell me why. ROBERT (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Yes, correct. I think, for me, it comes down to the burden of proof. And I don't feel the prosecution has laid out-- SANDY (ph): Yes. ROBERT (ph): --a real game plan, or really proved any of the allegations, beyond a reasonable doubt.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Tony (ph) on the end is an attorney. She says she's ready to vote for Joe Biden.TONY (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And feels Donald Trump is guilty.How come? TONY (ph): Yes. I mean, whether Trump intended to protect his family, or Stormy threatens to come forward, he still participated in falsifying documents and attempts to influence the election. I mean, if he wanted to pay the hush money, this happened in 2006, he would have paid it years ago. And the NDA from 2016 shows his awareness, of what took place.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.On the top row on the left, this is Scott (ph). Scott (ph) doesn't know who he's going to vote for November. And he doesn't know if Donald Trump is guilty or not guilty. How come you feel that way, at this point? SCOTT (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: I think the prosecution made it about Michael Cohen, when they let him open his mouth. And he turned out to be the worst star witness in the history of trials. So, good luck to the jurors, trying to figure out what's true, what's not.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, you're the juror right now. But you're saying you haven't decided. You don't like Cohen. But you haven't decided that he's not guilty?SCOTT (ph): Yes, I -- as an American, I also didn't have the ability, to see things through an unfiltered lens. So that would have really helped.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: This is DeLancey's (ph) son, Roscoe (ph)--DELANCEY (ph): Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Voting in your first presidential election in November.ROSCOE (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Says he's voting for Donald Trump. No?ROSCOE (ph): No. DELANCEY (ph): No.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Got it. Just checking you there, Roscoe (ph), because I see how nervous you were.You're voting for Joe Biden, you said. ROSCOE (ph): Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: But you think Donald Trump is guilty too.ROSCOE (ph): Yes, I, unlike most people, I kind of liked Michael Cohen's testimony. And I thought it was a strong one, based on what I heard from the court reports, and how the jury seemed to really resonate with them. And I think that the prosecution's attempt of trying to de-credit him, mostly served as a way of de-crediting Trump who was in charge of hiring him.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: OK. And this is Matt (ph), over here. Matt (ph) is ready to vote for Donald Trump in November, and he feels he's not guilty. How come?MATT (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Yes, sir. I believe, basically, with the Michael Cohen's testimony, it was just going to be basically just a lie from the beginning, from the idea of just as information he gave.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.And Matt (ph) and Belizza (ph) are a couple there. Belizza (ph), also, you're ready to vote for Donald Trump. You feel he's not guilty. How come? BELIZZA (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: Yes, I believe he's innocent, because I think he didn't violate any campaign financial law.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: OK. Belizza (ph) is from Colombia, originally.BELIZZA (ph): Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: And she became an American citizen, a few years ago.BELIZZA (ph): Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: So congratulations on that.And finally, Darrell (ph) is up there. He's ready to vote for Joe Biden, feels Donald Trump is guilty. How come? DARRELL (ph), GEORGIA VOTER: You can't explain -- can't explain away the receipts. He did what he did. And regardless if you think, is lying or not lying, the receipts remain, the documents remain.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Final question for you, a show of hands here. If Donald Trump is found guilty, do any of you who say you're ready to vote for Donald Trump, would you consider switching to Joe Biden? Raise your hands.No consideration, even if he's found guilty. Other hand, if he's found not guilty, any of you voting for Joe Biden, would you then possibly consider Donald Trump? All right, everyone's sticking with the candidates they have right now. We may find out guilty or not guilty, as early as tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TUCHMAN
utterances.sentences: Anderson, back to you.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Gary Tuchman, thanks so much.Back now with the panel. Interesting to hear how--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: It's not good news for Donald Trump, man. I mean, they go right along political lines. I mean, that seems to be it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: They went 100 percent.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: And you're talking to a jury pool. Just so you know, the jury pool comes from the voter pool. The voter pool here, I don't know, Anderson, you might -- what is it, 83-17?

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Something like that.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Yes, something along those lines. So that is--

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It seems to take acquittal--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --not good news.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It seems to take acquittal completely off the table. I mean, if the--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well I'm sure of that (ph).

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: --if the jury looks anything like that. Which is why, the reporting, tonight, from our own Paula Reid is that the Trump team, they think their best chance is a hung jury. And it may very well be if the jury decides that they really, really can't make this work.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: And that's why this thing about the Allen charge potentially could be important.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: Anything--

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And by the way, does the Allen charge have to happen, or you know--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. If they're stuck, the judge will eventually tell them, you need to make a decision.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Eventually is the key word.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: It's usually it's this -- there's no law. It's usually the third time. So, you get one -- we're hopelessly deadlocked. And then can we hear this readback, that -- this readback? OK. Now, the next day or hours later, we're hopelessly deadlocked.And then, the third one, the judge says, look, we've all been killing ourselves, including the 12 of you, to reach a verdict. And it's not like -- if you pass, it's just going to be 12 other jurors, who are going to have to do this.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: So please go, start negotiations from the beginning, start from like deliberations from the beginning, if need be, and reconsider the evidence as well.

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: But it has to be said, hung juries are rare, about 5 percent, 6 percent of all juries, a little more common in high-profile cases.This is a jury that I think every one of them is going to try hard to apply the law, to the evidence and come to a decision.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I think the important thing, though, to look at that is that this is not just all happening, in what happens with this verdict. It's also the question of what is the aftermath, and since as we are five months out from the campaign.And the thing that we saw today that we have never seen, in this trial so far, is Biden sending his allies, and his campaign surrogates, to the park, outside of the court, to come and talk about this.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And one of them was asked, why are you guys here? I believe it was the deputy campaign manager. And he said, we're here because you guys are here, talking to the reporters, who are outside, covering this trial.And I think that is a question. Because we are told President Biden is going to weigh in on this verdict, whatever it is, once we do have it from this jury. And so, it is a question of whether it's an acquittal, if it's something that helps fuel Trump's campaign, or if it's in any way, anything that impacts his run.

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: When you guys were in the courtroom, today, I was outside the courtroom. I had a quick case on. And then, I came outside.And I didn't -- I'm talking to the court officer. I go, what's going on over there? It's pandemonium. And they're like, oh, Bob De Niro's over there, giving a speech. And then, when he left, I don't know what security was around him, but it was -- it was insane--

utterances.speaker: AIDALA
utterances.sentences: --like I've never insane, because there's so many such international media there to begin with. And it's Bobby De Niro. And they are just following him. And it was the Trump people are screaming. It was like nothing I've ever seen.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And it all raises the question about whether -- I mean, look, the Biden campaign can rationalize. The media is there, sure.But the American people have largely made up their minds about this guy, Donald Trump. They know how they feel, probably about this case. And it doesn't matter. At the end of the day, I think what the jury's verdict is, in terms of how people already feel about his guilt or innocence.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Which is why I thought that was such a fascinating exercise that Gary Tuchman just did. I mean, it was 100 percent political correlation--

utterances.speaker: EISEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: --to verdict correlation. He had four Trump voters on that mock jury. Four not-guilty votes. That is remarkable.And look, this--

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But they haven't been in the actual room. I mean, it's really hard to say.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Of course not.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: They haven't. It's very different when you're actually in the room. So, I don't think that anyone should -- I just don't want anyone watching that.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Do you think any of them would have changed based on what we just saw?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I don't want anyone watching that to think it's a translation of what this jury is going to do. We don't know.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: But it's a fact -- no, of course not.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: It's also--

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: But it's a fascinating exercise that it--

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: --that it breaks 100 percent.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: And the four that were against him that were for acquittal would never have come over.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: I don't care what they saw. That was clear. And same vice versa. This is -- there is a political aspect. It's inseparable here.
